DOC.HEAD: Noriega Was Warned of Impending U.S. Invasion, Sources Say
Eds: INSERTS grafs after 7th graf, Taylor said, to include White House comment.
DOC.TEXT: Former Panamanian strongman Gen. Manuel Noriega was tipped off two days in advance of the United States' plans to invade his country, Bush administration sources say in a published report. Sources were divided on exactly how and when the former strongman, who managed to evade the U.S. military and later sought refuge in the Vatican Embassy, was warned. But one source told The Washington Times there is ``hard evidence'' the tipoff came in the form of a telephone call to Panama from the State Department about 48 hours before the military operation was launched at 1 a.m. Dec. 20. The call was intercepted by a National Security Agency listening post near Panama City, sources said. ``There was a leak tipping Noriega before it was coming,'' one government official said. ``We don't know who it was, but we believed it was somebody at State.'' Pentagon spokesman Bob Taylor denied Noriega was warned, saying, ``We don't have any indication at this time that there was a major OPSEC (operational security) problem.'' Taylor said a captured Noriega bodyguard told U.S. interrogators the Panamanian leader was informed of the military action about three hours before it happened but refused to believe the information. In Corpus Christi, Texas, where President Bush was vacationing, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater said he had no information to give out on the report. In any event, Fitzwater said, ``it's history now.'' According to the newspaper, administration sources said some Noriega forces and the general himself knew in advance about the operation, dubbed Operation Just Cause. The sources based their assessment, in part, on four incidents: _The night before the military intervention, Cuban MiG-21s ``shadowed'' C-141 Starlifters carrying U.S. Army paratroopers from Pope Air Force Base, N.C., to Panama, the sources said. The Pentagon is investigating whether one of the Cuban planes may have fired its cannon as a warning shot. Noriega, with his relationship with the United States crumbling in recent years, had increasingly turned to Cuba for military and intelligence support, according to administration sources. _Noriega intensified his nocturnal activities two days before the U.S. assault, and the Pentagon has ``indications'' he visited the Cuban Embassy at one point the night of Dec. 19-20 but left when U.S. troops surrounded the compound, sources said. _Panamanian Defense Forces appeared to be lying in wait and opened fire on Navy SEAL, or sea-air-land, commandoes who parachuted into the area of Panama's small Paitilla Airport, where the deposed leader maintained his private jet. The Pentagon said four SEAL members were killed. _Noriega's most elite jungle warfare unit had vanished from its battalion's facility when U.S. troops arrived to attack. The deposed Noriega today remained holed up in the Vatican embassy in Panama City, where he sought asylum on Christmas Eve. A Panamanian official said new President Guillermo Endara's government sent a letter to the Vatican asking that Noriega be expelled. The official, who spoke on condition of anonymity, said he did not know whether the government asked that Noriega be turned over to U.S. authorities or to Panama. In Texas, where President Bush was hunting, White House spokesman Marlin Fitzwater reiterated the U.S. stance that Noriega should be handed over to the United States to stand trial on drug trafficking charges. Vatican spokesman Joaquin Navarro said in Rome that officials still hoped to resolve the crisis within days, but he gave no details.
